content: A reader sends along a question about exporting graphs from Rstudio.
I discuss why an ongoing data collection effort makes me very picky about writing complete and clear hypotheses.
I discuss a chapter on "classy" in Howard Becker's book on writing and remember writing similarly not too long ago.
I discuss a problem for those who oppose multiply imputing outcome variables--namely, they use models that "impute" outcome variables all the time!
I provide a couple of links for creating coefficient plots in Stata.
I discuss my ideas about a linear models class, emphasizing building a model from substantive ideas and drawing conclusions from the model.
I discuss the resistance to testing research hypotheses that variables have or do not have a meaningful effect.
I discuss two Google Chrome apps that help me sort through and engage an increasingly demanding and frustrating amount of information on the internet.
I muse about the role of political methodologists within political science and use two successful papers to illustrate properties of useful methods papers.
There has been some discussion lately on my blog about whether odds-ratios are the best way to communicate results from a logistic regression model. I say "absolutely not" and explain why.
